entry.title: Using Gulp to Bundle, Minify, and Cache-bust
entry.content:
Last week I discussed how to setup Node.js and Gulp in Visual Studio 2015.Â  During that discussion, I mentioned that Iâ€™m using gulp to bundle, minify and cache-bust my HTML, CSS, and JavaScript files.

This week, my intent is to walk you through exactly how I do that.

So, if you donâ€™t already have Node.js and Gulp installed, you may want to go back and read the article I wrote last week.

Since most of the people who read this blog are ASP.NET developers, there may be a few .NET specific tips along the way.Â  But the Gulp file I am going to walk you through is technology agnostic.Â  So if you are using some other technology, youâ€™ll still benefit from this article.

Bundling

The first thing we want to do is that we want to combine all of our CSS files and JavaScript files into one file for CSS and one file for JavaScript.Â  There are several ways that you might do this, but what I wanted was some way that would allow me to work unbundled during development and bundled when I released the code.Â  Since Iâ€™m working with a single page application (SPA), this was a simple matter of configuring my default file to be index.debug.html for development and index.release.html and using web.config transforms to specify which should be used in which environment.Â  If you are working in some other environment, Iâ€™m sure you have some kind of similar way of specifying the default file based on an environment setting.

So all of my development work will be done in index.debug.html.

Like I said, there are many ways of bundling JavaScript and CSS code, but the way Iâ€™ve found that seems to have the least amount of work involved is by using the gulp-useref module.Â  This module lets us put tokens in our html file that specify which files we want to compress and what the resulting file name should be.

Map Files

Once we have all of our files minified, weâ€™ll want some way of being able to see the original source code even though you have a minified file that the site is using.Â  Iâ€™m not going to go into a lot of detail about what a map file is or what it does here.Â  But if you have a problem on a production server, you are going to want to at least have map files available so you can track the issue down. Next we need to get the files that are in our index directory back out to the directories they belong in.Â  To do this, we use the built-in node command gulp.dest().

Cache-busting

One of the age-old problems of using CSS and JavaScript pages on our site is that when we put new versions up, we have no way of telling the browser that we just put a new file up unless we change the file name.Â  The trick is to make the file look like a new file.Â  This is typically done by putting a query parameter at the end.

Once again, there are several solutions to this problem available for Gulp, but the one I like the best reads the file and generates a hash string for it and appends that as the query string.Â  This make the file look unique but only causes the browser to download the file if it really is different.
